'TheravÄda' is the oldest surviving branch of Buddhism. Sherab Chodzin Kohn.
A Life of the Buddha, p149-p150. Shambhala Publications, 1993. The word is
derived from the Sanskrit [[sthaviravada]], and literally means "the Teaching of
the Elders". It is relatively conservative, and according to Dr. Rupert Gethin,
it is closer to early Buddhism than other existing Buddhist
traditions. Gethin, Rupert. The Foundations of Buddhism, p1. Oxford
University Press, 1998.

*In Southeast Asia: **Cambodia (by 95% of the population) **Laos (by 67% of the

*In other parts of Asia: **China (mainly by the Shan and Tai ethnic groups)
**Vietnam (by the Khmer Krom) **Malaysia (by 19.2% of the population)
**Indonesia (by 0.72% of the population) **Singapore is where recently TheravÄda
